programs.title: Programme of work on Marine and Coastal iodiversity

action.en: By 2020, at least 17 per cent of terrestrial and inland water, and 10 per cent of coastal and marine areas, especially areas of particular importance for biodiversity and ecosystem services, are conserved through effectively and equitably managed, ecologically representative and well connected systems of protected areas and other effective area-based conservation measures, and integrated into the wider landscapes and seascapes.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 11 by Chrissy Grant
20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 11 by Trevor Sandwith

activities.title_s: In 2011, by Decree of the Ministry of the Environment, Energy and Technology, the first “seamounts” marine management area was declared around Isla del Coco. (NBSAP)
In 2014, the Law on the Protected Areas System entered into force. (NBSAP)

NBSAP 2015-2020 highlights the need to establish marine protected areas (MPAs) and identify and adopt measures for vulnerable species.  Planned activities include inter alia: awareness-raising activities on responsible fishing and co-management processes for local communities, and  creating and/or strengthening organizational structures (e.g. community associations) involving fishermen, industry, etc.; investigating the potential impact of oil exploitation on fisheries and identifying appropriate measures to take in this regard; developing MPA management plans and MPA support projects (including through ecotourism). The first NBSAP (2005) was successful in establishing 30% of the country’s territory as protected areas, and the designation of the Island of Principe as a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. (NBSAP)

NBSAP 2016-2020 contains 4 national targets mapped to ABT11 which inter alia aim to: expand the marine protected area network and develop and implement at least one or two protected area management plans by 2020; and establish community-based management plans for fisheries and mangroves by 2018. In 2010, Kiribati became the world leader in marine conservation after declaring the Phoenix Islands (408 250 sq km) a marine protected area (PIPA). In 2013, Kiribati exceeded the marine target set out under Aichi Biodiversity Target 11 (12% of territorial waters are protected). In January 2015, the entire PIPA area was officially closed to commercial fishing. (NBSAP)

NBSAP (2016-2020) indicates that the Strategy and State Program of Conservation and Use of Specially Protected Nature Areas (SPNAs) was adopted through a decision of the Government of the Republic of Armenia in 2014.  Emphasis is placed on the importance of increasing the level of landscape representativeness, in addition to species that are registered in the Armenian Red Book, in SPNAs.  In 2013, the Khosrov Forest State Reserve was awarded with the European Diploma on Protected Areas by the European Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe, representing the first such case in the region. (NBSAP)

NBSAP (2018-2050) contains 4 national targets that are mapped to ABT11, among which includes the target to identify and prioritize, by 2020, key biodiversity areas (KBAs) within and outside the protected areas system. Panama’s system of protected areas (SINAP) is comprised of representative samples of 12 life zones and a variety of ecosystems, occupying 31.8% of the country’s land area and 13.5% of its marine area. Considerable attention is being given to developing “green tourism” in protected areas, in accordance with both national and international standards. This initiative is supported by an Action Plan for the 2016-2026 period and being promoted by the Ministry of Environment, the Tourism Authority and the National Institute of Culture, together with civil society, communities and the private sector. (NBSAP)

Several categories of protected areas exist, the most significant of which are the Natura 2000 Special Areas of Conservation (SACs) under the Habitats Directive and the Special Protection Areas (SPAs) under the Birds Directive (there are 430 SACs and 154 SPAs covering 1,949,253 ha, of which 907,754 ha is terrestrial/freshwater). In terms of Natural Heritage Area (NHA), peatland sites are at present the only statutorily designated NHAs and recognized in County Development Plans and other local area development plans. Under Objective 6 of the National Biodiversity Action Plan (2017-2021), actions are planned to inter alia: complete the designation process for SACs and SPAs, particularly for marine coastal and offshore SPAs; implement the National Peatland Strategy; implement the National Raised Bog Special Areas of Conservation (SAC) Management Plan (2017-2022); taking climate change into account, ensure that there are no significant adverse effects from marine fisheries and aquaculture in and adjacent to Natura 2000 sites; increase protected areas connectivity; and extend the MPA network (involving spatial planning). Lead and key partners and performance indicators are defined.  (NBSAP)

The protected areas system in Benin comprises 58 forests covering 1,292,543 ha or 30% of the nation’s land area.  (The National Parks “W” and Pendjari, situated in the northern part of the country, together with buffer zones, cover 777,000 ha or 7% of the nation’s land area). Protected areas represent the only biodiverse areas in the country (outside of protected areas, biodiversity is rare).  In 2018, only 1% of the country’s marine biodiversity was protected.  Activities are underway to create a marine protection zone for the long-term conservation of species, particularly sea turtles.  (6NR)

It is stipulated in the Constitution that the land belongs to the indigenous ‘custom owners’. Almost all of the land is under customary tenure. Activities are continuing in relation to National Target 1 which aims to, by 2030, increase the representativeness of terrestrial and coastal and marine ecosystems to support 100% of local communities’ livelihoods and 'kastom' importance, and are mainstreamed with the National Sustainable Development Plan (2016-2030). Two conservation management systems are being used, including community and customary governance or management (‘kastom’), and a government management system, supported by the Department of Environmental Protection and Conservation (DEPC), covered under the Environmental Protection and Conservation (EPC) Act. The DEPC recognizes that resource management through traditional means constitutes the basis for conservation in the country. Under the EPC Act, it is possible for Community Conservation Areas (CCAs) to be registered by communities. CCAs are intended to complement traditional management and provide communities with the option to enforce legal protection over their resources. There are also hundreds of informal conservation areas that exist under customary protection.  The DEPC is particularly interested in supporting CCAs of national biodiversity significance.  Vanuatu is on track to achieve National Target 2 which aims to, by 2020, have 10 legally registered CCAs with 50% of CCAs effectively supported and managed.   Other national targets are also contributing to the achievement of ABT11. (6NR)

Progress has been made in relation to the expansion of the terrestrial and inland waters protected areas network, and the formal establishment of the Emerald Network (the country anticipates reaching the 17% target).  However, efforts are required to build the coastal and marine protected areas network (the target of 10% will not be reached.) New conservation approaches, such as contractual nature conservation, have been initiated to enhance the creation of ecological corridors between protected areas. In addition, 31 Important Bird Areas (IBAs), totalling 1,432,960 ha, have been identified and mapped.  A significant part of IBAs is currently included in the national protected areas system or Emerald Network (those outside of these areas are considered potential protected areas or Emerald Network sites). (6NR)

In 2016, an area including a 2-mile radius around St. Kitts and Nevis was declared as a “Marine Management Area” with the passing of the Fisheries, Aquaculture and Marine Resources Act (FAMRA). Three areas (Sandy Point, Keys and The Narrows) totaling 11,693 ha within this zone have been declared as “Conservation Zones” to protect the coral reefs, seagrass beds, fish stocks and other aquatic life that depend on these areas, including the Spiny lobster and the Queen Conch. In addition, since submission of the 5NR, 2 new terrestrial protected areas have been proposed, one of which, Booby Island Nature Reserve (300 ha), has been legally declared. The Nevis Peak National Park and Camps River Watershed Area (3,250 ha) remains proposed. (6NR)

At November 2017, approximately 16.2% of Germany’s terrestrial surface area and 44.9% of its marine surface area (including the EEZ) are protected under the following categories: Natura 2000 network, national parks, core area and buffer zones in biosphere reserves, nature conservation areas and natural monuments. Categories that are not taken into account in these figures are: transition zones in biosphere reserves, landscape conservation areas and nature parks.  It is acknowledged that, in addition to expanding the protected areas network, it is important that actions taken toward ABT11 also consider the need to improve the quality of protected areas. Based on criteria agreed by the Federal Government/Länder Working Group on Nature Conservation, Landscape Management and Recreation, actions are regularly taken to ensure the quality level of national park management. In addition, UNESCO biosphere reserves are evaluated every 10 years using the prescribed criteria. The quality of nature parks is audited through a voluntary scheme. (6NR)

programs.title: Programme of work on Protected Areas

action.en: By 2020 the extinction of known threatened species has been prevented and their conservation status, particularly of those most in decline, has been improved and sustained.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 12 by Vital Bambanze
20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 12 by Russ Mittermeier

activities.title_s: The Transboundary Biosphere Reserve “Monviso” (Italy/France) was inscribed in the MAB Programme in 2013, following efforts to integrate the management of 2 PAs (Parco del Po Cuneese and Parc National Régional du Queyras) and conserve biodiversity in the alpine ecological corridor. (NBSAP)
Endangered sea turtles are being conserved in cooperation with international organizations.  Turtle hatching stations have been established in the Nga Pu Taw and Bogalay townships. (NBSAP)

A Directive from the President has been instrumental in protecting the threatened shea tree and in stimulating the development of a National Strategy for its protection to be completed in 2014. (NBSAP)

National Target 6 of NBSAP 2016-2020, mapped to achieving ABT12, aims to implement conservation measures for 100% of identified priority species by 2020. This target is divided into 4 specific targets: identification of priority species (flora and fauna); implementation of conservation plans for priority species (as well as CEPA activities for the population); implementation of a monitoring system for priority species; and capacity-building for agents involved in monitoring activities. Seventeen priority actions are defined, with those related to capacity-building for agents prioritized among them. Each priority action is linked to a performance indicator (and to the entity responsible for monitoring it), as well as to entities responsible for ensuring implementation of the priority action. (NBSAP)

Preliminary Target 2 of the country’s first NBSAP 2014-2017 is mapped to ABT12. Its strategic orientation was to continue ongoing assessments of the status of Afghani floral and faunal species to enhance understanding of them and their conservation needs. Short-term actions were linked to inter alia continuation of the national red-listing process being carried out by the Afghanistan Wildlife Executive Committee using IUCN’s regional criteria. Medium-term actions were linked to determining the status of national biodiversity, identifying biodiversity hotspots and setting protection targets, undertaking field studies of selected species and ecosystems, and developing biodiversity information systems. Afghanistan is not considered a global biodiversity hotspot due mainly to its relatively low number of endemic vertebrates (7 species); however, the number of endemic plants is relatively high (possibly more than 1,000 species). (NBSAP)

Target 9 of NBSAP 2016-2020 aims to protect wild animal and plant species listed in the National Red Data Book, and stabilize and increase populations of globally endangered species, including the European Bison, Greater Spotted Eagle, Great Snipe, Black-tailed Godwit, Aquatic Warbler, among others. Ten actions are defined. Anticipated results include inter alia: identification and transfer of at least 1500 habitats of wild animals and 1000 habitats of wild plants, listed in the National Red Data Book, to land users and/or water users for protection; development and implementation of measures for globally endangered bird species; implementation of at least 20 action plans for wild animal and wild plant species listed in the National Red Data Book; study of 28 insufficiently-studied species of wild animals (including reasons for their decline and proposal of measures). It is anticipated that actions taken in relation to the European Bison result in the development of a method to recover its natural forage base, a system of genetic certification of its micro-populations, and development of a long-term genetic program for the selection of breeding pairs to increase genetic diversity of its micro-populations. (NBSAP)

NBSAP 2016-2021 indicates that the country has 7 Alliance for Zero Extinction species (including Jamaica Ground Iguana, Jamaican Pauraque, Jamaica Petrel, and Portland Ridge Frog) in 5 Alliance for Zero Extinction sites. (NBSAP)

The country’s first NBSAP addresses ABT12 under Primary Objective 1 which seeks to guarantee legally-binding protection for biodiversity. Four priority areas deal with: creation of legal instruments to protect endangered species and ecosystems; promotion of the legal environmental framework (relates to CEPA); development of good hunting practices and sustainable management of the hunting sector; and integration of the concept of biodiversity in draft laws on land management. Six actions are planned, with priority given to developing, by 2020, a new management plan for fauna and hunting, taking into account the status and trends of huntable species. The five other actions have a 2025 implementation timeframe. (NBSAP)

The Wildlife Conservation Law is currently being amended to take into account CITES instruments for threatened species.  Also, combating wildlife trafficking is one of the three key themes addressed by the West Africa Biodiversity and Climate Change (WABiCC) Program. Liberia is a major beneficiary of this Program, whose implementation has inter alia facilitated the training of 36 judges and prosecutors as well as 12 law students in the enforcement of regulations and prosecution of wildlife crime. (6NR)

Although a definitive assessment of the status of threatened species is not available, it is probable that the survival odds for threatened species on the National Red List are declining. Of particular concern is the fact that most habitats of threatened species are located outside of protected areas. The hunting pressure on vertebrate species is significant, with several animals considered to be near or at risk of extinction continuing to be sold on the major markets in the country. In 2018, the Prime Minister issued an order directing Ministers, the Vientiane Capital Governor and Provincial Governors to strictly enforce wildlife laws, and comply with national laws on wildlife trade management and inspection and international commitments. Support is being provided to implement the Lao Wildlife Law Enforcement Network at provincial and district levels. The network’s primary objective is to reduce illegal wildlife trade (actions are being carried out to inter alia build the capacity of staff to detect such activities, disrupt organized crime networks and prosecute offenders). In this regard, actions are also being taken to enhance cooperation between law enforcement agencies in Thailand, Myanmar and Lao PDR. (6NR)

There is a slight increase in the populations of forest butterflies and birds; a significant increase in the population of the Griffon Vulture; and a slight increase in the populations of large carnivores. However, there has been a drastic decline in the presence of the Eastern Imperial Eagle in Europe (today this Eurasian species is more present in the Mongolian and Kazakh steppes). Also, results of permanent monitoring of the Steppe Falcon in Serbia over the last 2 decades indicate a significant decline (69%) in population size (due potentially to illegal killing). In December 2018, the Ministry of Environmental Protection introduced a permanent fishing ban on sterlet. (6NR)

As a result of implementation of the Orinoco Crocodile Conservation Program (Programa de Conservación del Caimán del Orinoco), 10,512 individuals raised in captivity were released into the wild between 1990 and 2018.  Three populations were completely re-introduced.  The Orinoco Crocodile is found only in freshwater environments, particularly the Orinoco River and its tributaries, in Venezuela and Colombia. It is critically endangered. During the early to middle1900s, the species was excessively hunted for its skin and came close to extinction. (6NR)

Various action plans and guidelines for species protection have been prepared further to international conventions, the EU Birds and Habitat Directives, and national laws.  For example: an action plan has been drafted for the conservation of the wolf; an interregional action plan was prepared for the conservation of the brown bear in the central-eastern Alps; and an action plan for the conservation of the Marsican brown bear has also been prepared.  In 2018, management plans for the sustainable hunting of bird species with an unfavourable conservation status (Birds Directive) were prepared.  In 2016, 3 manuals were published for monitoring species and habitats of Community interest (a National Monitoring Plan is currently under development). Between 2014 and 2018, work was carried out to update the National Red List. LIFE projects being carried out in Italy relate to the Egyptian vulture, FLORANET (plant species of Community interest in the central Italian Apennines), and SEPOSSO (Italian governance of Posidonia oceanica transplants, a marine habitat of priority Community interest). (6NR)

action.en: By 2020, the genetic diversity of cultivated plants and farmed and domesticated animals and of wild relatives, including other socio-economically as well as culturally valuable species, is maintained, and strategies have been developed and implemented for minimizing genetic erosion and safeguarding their genetic diversity.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 13 by Maria Yolanda Teran Maigua
20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 13 by Vandana Shiva

activities.title_s: The Ministry of Agriculture has set up 6 national bureaus (plant genetic resources, animal genetic resources, fish genetic resources, agriculturally important insects, agriculturally important microorganisms and soil sciences) to conserve rich domesticated biodiversity and promote underutilized crops and animal breeds. (NBSAP)

Efforts are now being made to domesticate some plants used in traditional medicine. Accordingly, the National Agency for Genetic Resources and Biotechnology is mandated to document and keep essential genetic biodiversity. The National Institute for Pharmaceutical Research and Development also has reliable data on the medicinal and patent value of plant resources in Nigeria. (NBSAP)

National Target 8 of NBSAP 2014-2030 is mapped to ABT13 and included under National Priority 4, to be implemented jointly by Government, universities and research institutions by 2025.  Planned actions focus on: developing and updating inventory on genetic resources (phytogenetic and agrogenetic) and developing/supporting and implementing a conservation program for them; encouraging the implementation of cross-breeding programs for domestic animals and cultivated varieties to improve these biological resources without losing the best features of existing local genetic heritage; and promoting exchanges and establishing protocols with institutions associated to genetic preservation.  There are three indicators defined for National Target 8: number of inventories on plant genetic resources prepared or updated; number of legal instruments (seeds) passed; patenting of at least x varieties of plants of economic and cultural value. (NBSAP)

Under Action 9.3 of the National Policy on Biological Diversity 2016-2025, the country aims to develop a National Strategy for Ex Situ Conservation. The following measures are being considered in this context: establishing a national network of botanical gardens; enhancing or  establishing nurseries and introduction programmes for threatened species and varieties of trees and other plants, and captive breeding and reintroduction programmes; ensuring that zoos and wildlife parks are managed to a high standard, safeguarding animal welfare and promoting conservation; enhancing seed and germplasm gene banks for microorganisms, fungi, plants and animals; strengthening national, regional and international cooperation on ex situ conservation. To contribute to food security, 12,258 rice accessions from indigenous, wild and cultivated sources are currently being conserved in the country’s gene banks. (NBSAP)

Under Goal 5 “Halting the loss of biological and landscape diversity and development of ecological network” of the National Action Plan on Environmental Protection (2011-2015), the country aimed to create a gene bank of flora species listed in the Red Data Book of Ukraine within the January 2012 - December 2015 timeframe. (NBSAP)

The National Biodiversity Strategy 2015-2030 contains four national targets that are mapped to ABT13. By 2017, the country aimed to have established two Bio-Knowledge Centres in selected provinces for conserving local agrobiodiversity; and to have increased production systems for agricultural biodiversity by 10%, taking into account the knowledge and experiences of women and men of Indigenous communities and ethnic groups.  By 2021, the country aims to have consolidated the National Germplasm Bank of native species for food and agriculture and associated wild species; as well as implemented a certified and updated National Seed Bank including all species considered to be useful at this point in time. (NBSAP)

activities.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
activities.title_s: The Scottish Strategy (2020 Challenge for Scotland’s Biodiversity) published in 2013 highlights that farmed and cultivated biodiversity, and associated genetic diversity, constitute an important part of Scotland’s natural capital. The relevance of traditional knowledge to this area is also highlighted. Work is being undertaken by numerous bodies, including the Farm Animal Genetic Resources Expert Committee and the UK Plant Genetic Resources Group.  Related programmes include inter alia the Scottish Landrace Protection Scheme, administered by Science and Advice for Scottish Agriculture (SASA), which promotes continuation of the practice of using traditional varieties of farm animals and crops in the country’s island communities.  (NBSAP)

In Somaliland, a seed bank has been established which aims to collect and store local seeds that are of good quality and that have greater resistance to the local climate. Other aims are to the reduce the risks associated with the use of foreign seeds (such as the introduction of new diseases), as well as ensure the availability of less expensive seeds and local seed production. Another seed bank has been established in Cuun village in Puntland State however is not yet operationalized. (6NR)

Ongoing efforts to conserve locally-cultivated crops in particular and promote their future cultivation are being led by the Ministry of Agriculture. Through the Ministry’s National Directorate for Research, Statistics and GIS, 92 local species have been collected from 6 municipalities (Baucau, Lautem, Liquica, Manufahi, Maliana and Viqueque) since 2014, and are now stored at the collection centres of Loes and Betano to be further developed. In addition, through the ‘Seeds of Life’ project, a national seed system was established in 2016 to ensure that good seed of improved varieties is produced annually to meet the national seed requirement (33%). Crops such as maize, rice, peanut, sweet potato, kidney bean, mung bean, cassava and, recently, a purple sweet potato from Baucau, have been released and distributed to farmers for cultivation. (6NR)

The National Program on the Conservation and Sustainable Use of Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (2017-2020), aligned with the Second Global Plan of Action for Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture, is currently under implementation. Plant genetic resources on all accessions related to original and traditional agricultural plants at threat of disappearing are deposited in the Croatian Plant Genetic Resources Database (CPGRD).  In addition, the National Program of Conservation of Indigenous and Protected Breeds of Domesticated Animals adopted in 2010 remains in place. Furthermore, the Operational Program for the Establishment of a Gene Bank of Domesticated Animals in the Republic of Croatia was adopted by the Ministry of Agriculture in 2012.  Under the Rural Development Program of the Republic of Croatia (2014-2020), financial support is provided for preservation, sustainable use and development of genetic resources in agriculture. (6NR)

Since 2013, an Agrobiodiversity Fair has taken place each year in the canton of Talamanca. This event is promoted by the Talamanca-Caribbean Biological Corridor Association and IUCN and aims to conserve and rescue biodiversity for agriculture through strengthening protection of native seeds and knowledge about cultivation practices. It also serves as a nature-based solution to assist farmers adapt to climate change. In 2018, 210 producers exchanged seed, non-timber forest products, and related knowledge. Also, the Sancarleña Network of Rural Women (Rescamur) has been organized by women from the canton. Native seeds are contributed by members throughout the year and exchanged at an annual fair. The Network is currently preparing a recipe book called ‘Seed Sanctuary as the basis of the Rural Gastronomy’ and in charge of managing the ‘La Libre’ Agroecological Farm, dedicated to the conservation of natural species cultivated without agrochemicals or GMOs. The farm features inter alia educational trails, a forest nursery, medicinal plants and a seed sanctuary. (6NR)

The country is taking measures to conserve and promote the genetic diversity of crop plants through implementation of the National Action Plan for the Conservation and Sustainable Use of Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture.  A conceptual framework has been prepared to conserve agricultural livestock. Measures are being carried out to conserve and develop the genetic diversity of forests through implementation of near-natural silviculture with natural regeneration, conservation of locally adapted populations (and in relation to their potential adaptability in forests of particular genetic interest), and in the use of locally adapted reproductive material (seeds, seedlings) for artificial regeneration of populations.  However, there is a lack of data available on the development and status of genetic diversity of wild plants and animals due to the absence of appropriate monitoring programmes (it is recognized that efforts are required in this area). (6NR)

Global Strategy for Plan Conservation

action.en: By 2020, ecosystems that provide essential services, including services related to water, and contribute to health, livelihoods and well-being, are restored and safeguarded, taking into account the needs of women, indigenous and local communities, and the poor and vulnerable.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 14 by Claude Fromageot
20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 14 by Carlos Manuel Rodriguez

activities.title_s: In July 2013, the province of Saskatchewan designated a new protected area in the provincial boreal forest, the Pink Lake Representative Area Ecological Reserve. At 3,660 km2, it is Saskatchewan’s largest protected area. With the Pink Lake designation, protected area coverage in the Churchill River Upland Ecoregion increases from 4.9% to 8.2%. As an ecological reserve, no new industrial development will be allowed in the area. Leases or permits in place at the time of the designation will be grandfathered to allow existing activities to continue. Traditional activities by First Nations and Métis people, as well as recreational hunting and angling, will continue. (NBSAP)

NBSAP (2012) contains 10 ecosystem-specific targets (in addition to 20 national-level targets). All 30 targets are linked to priority actions, timeframes for action, performance indicators and actors/organizations responsible for implementation.  (NBSAP)

NBSAP 2015-2020 contains 2 national targets mapped to ABT14. By the end of 2016, the country aimed to have published a national assessment of the status of all services (provisioning, regulating and cultural) provided by natural systems, including an assessment of their importance to both rural and urban populations, and options to ensure their sustainable use. Relatedly, by the end of 2018, the country aimed to have developed a national strategy and subnational strategies for the sustainable management of ecosystems and provision of ecosystem services for rural and urban populations. The NBSAP also indicates that activities are planned to: provide training on ecosystem services for academics, researchers, field teams, local organizations of volunteer or conservation groups, technical employees from governmental bodies; and in relation to CEPA for parliamentarians, decision-makers, religious leaders, opinion leaders, communities, women and youth. (NBSAP)

Specific Objective 4.3 of NBSAP 2017-2025 is mapped to ABT14 and ABT15 and aims to evaluate and map ecosystems and their services with the objective of improving their status.  Five activities are associated to varying implementation timeframes through to 2025. Anticipated outcomes include: preparation of a revised map of ecosystem services at the national level and a list of priorities for restoration and enhancement of ecosystems and their services; assessment of the economic value of certain ecosystem services in a number of pilot areas; establishment of an intersectoral working group; preparation and implementation of a number of intersectoral projects for improving ecosystem status; and provision of training for staff members in the nature protection sector in ecosystem services mapping, status assessment and valuation. Entities involved in implementation include inter alia regional and local self-government units. (NBSAP)

Sub-objective 2.7 of the National Biodiversity Action Plan 2012-2016 outlines “desired actions” in relation to ecosystem valuation, including preparation of an overview of measurable services provided by Suriname’s ecosystems, and conduct of a pilot project on capitalization of ecosystem services (pricing of products/services).  Work was also expected to be conducted on inter alia monitoring the effects of economic activities (e.g. mining, agriculture, industry) on biodiversity, promoting responsible mining, addressing the spread of dangerous objects, substances or organisms in ecosystems, and improving access to information on ecosystems. The need to digitize existing maps and place digital data in a useful format was also highlighted. (NBSAP)

Considerable attention is given to the subject of ecosystem services in the National Biodiversity Strategy 2012-2020. National Target D-1, mapped to ABT14, aims to strengthen, by 2020, benefits derived from biodiversity and ecosystem services in Japan and elsewhere, with consideration given to the needs of women and local communities, and carry out work on each species with particular consideration given to the principles underpinning Satochi-Satoyama landscape management. Key action goals focus on: forest planning; regional-level community activities to conserve and manage regional resources, such as agricultural land and water; promotion at national and international levels of the Satoyama Initiative which aims to improve biodiversity, ecosystem services and human well-being in human-influenced natural environments, through agriculture, forestry and other human activities; promotion of the Green Reconstruction Project (part of reconstruction efforts being carried out pursuant to the 2011 Great East Japan Earthquake); restoration of coastal forests through the Green Bonds Regeneration Project; implementation of initiatives to create Satoumi areas (coastal areas where biological productivity and biodiversity have increased through human interaction); and development of new policies on the utilization of Biosphere Reserves, better known as “UNESCO Eco Parks” in the country.  (NBSAP)

Women are recognized as the primary land and natural resource managers in the country. The national gender mainstreaming guideline on biodiversity resources and ecosystem services has been developed and implemented (this has resulted in gender mainstreaming in annual plans for biodiversity and related sectors). Various initiatives, such as the “Leave No Women Behind” Programme and the Heroine/Jegnit Community Movement, are helping to empower Ethiopian women. The appointment of women to the Council of Ministers has reached 50%. (6NR)

As a result of cooperation between the Government, the private sector, communities and volunteer groups, there was a 40% decrease (20,143.4 ha to 12,896 ha) of forest area destroyed by wildlife fires between 2016 and 2017.  There has also been a movement built around implementing the Master Plan for Rehabilitating and Conserving Forests and Ecosystems in 25 water basins.  A work plan was also developed to protect muddy and sandy beaches from coastal erosion, including through nature-based solutions, such as the use of bamboo poles to create walls to decrease the magnitude of currents.  This has resulted in the rehabilitation of mangrove forests, raising awareness of the issue among the people in the area, and in an increase (and dissemination) of knowledge. (6NR)

Between 2015-2018, the project ‘AlpES - Alpine ecosystem services - mapping, conservation, and management’ was implemented to collect, analyze and distribute information on ecosystem services in the Alpine arc. Implemented by ten partners from six Alpine countries (Austria, France, Germany, Italy, Liechtenstein and Slovenia), the project aimed to introduce a common understanding of ecosystem services within a regional and transnational context, train and support target groups (involved in governance and the protection of ecosystems and their services, including state authorities, policy makers, NGOs, researchers and economic operators) in evaluating and managing ecosystem services.  As a result of the project, the concept of ecosystem services is now considered in decision-making processes.  The country has also recently carried out considerable work in relation to conservation of pollinators (bees and others) and soils. (6NR)

There are watershed management plans in place for two of seven watersheds. A Sectoral Adaptation Strategy and Action Plan for the Water Sector 2018-2028 is also being implemented which aims to build climate resilience and protect freshwater resources.  Participatory approaches to implementing projects on watershed ecosystem restoration are promoted, involving NGOs, CBOs, private entities, and charitable organisations, in addition to private landowners through the establishment of formal agreements with them. In 2018, a reforestation project commenced to stabilize 98 ha of slopes and soils in the Roseau watershed (the country’s most significant watershed) to improve water quality. By the end of 2018, a sizeable nursery of 28,800 plants had been established and 9060 wildlings and 615 cuttings planted on landslide areas. It is expected that these actions will help to stabilize 258.65 ha, significantly exceeding the target of 98 ha. (6NR)
Efforts are being taken to protect the quality of drinking water (groundwater), the country’s most important natural resource, through the designation of drinking water protected areas. (6NR)

Society for Ecological Restoration

action.en: By 2020, ecosystem resilience and the contribution of biodiversity to carbon stocks has been enhanced, through conservation and restoration, including restoration of at least 15 per cent of degraded ecosystems, thereby contributing to climate change mitigation and adaptation and to combating desertification.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 15 by Ben ten Brink
20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 15 by Sasha Alexander

activities.title_s: State programmes are being implemented to expand national forest coverage, green urban areas and rehabilitate ecological functioning in degraded forests. Wide-scale forest planting and greening initiatives have been undertaken over the last 5 years (10,131 ha of forest habitat are under active restoration). (NBSAP)
The country aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2021. (NBSAP)
Large mining companies are being encouraged to create conservation areas (e.g. cases of QIT Madagascar Minerals (QMM), Ambatovy). (NBSAP)

National Target 16, mapped to ABT15, of NBSAP 2011-2020 aims to have put in place, by 2018, a Measurement, Reporting and Verification (MRV) system to strengthen the resilience of ecosystems and biodiversity to climate change. Monitoring and evaluation actions would take into consideration factors related to deforestation and forest degradation, carbon (emission and sequestration) and non-carbon benefits (such as resilience and adaptation to climate change, forest resource governance, trees outside of forests). (NBSAP)

The 2019 addendum to the NBSAP (2009) is constituted by national targets mapped to the ABTs (4 of which are mapped to ABT15). Three 2020 targets aim to: enhance or restore natural ecosystems within 3 selected parks; restore and enhance the habitats of 3 coastal areas by incorporating design elements that are suitable for coastal substrates; and plant 25,000 trees and shrubs across the nature parks and nature reserves, as part of the Forest Restoration Action Plan 2019-2029. The fourth target aims to report, every two years, on the accounting of carbon stock and carbon flux in vegetation and land use. (NBSAP)

The National Biodiversity Strategy 2016-2025 contains 2 objectives mapped to ABT15.  Objective 3.4 (soil and mineral resources) aims to reduce the risk of water and wind erosion and increase organic matter contained in the soil. A priority measure is to complete, by 2020, the legislative process to amend the Act on the Protection of Agricultural Land Resources and consistently enforce legislative obligations. Objective 3.5 (ecosystem maintenance and restoration) aims to: reduce negative effects of suburbanization on the ecological stability of the landscape; improve the protection of significant landscape elements; increase the share of reclamation after mining through spontaneous succession; and improve landscape connectivity. Priority measures (2020) include inter alia: elaboration of a methodology to evaluate the use of developed areas; definition of areas in which construction activity can be carried out in zoning plans; examination of the adequacy of legislation on meadows conservation (vis-à-vis construction activity) and limiting areas in diluvial areas in which construction activity can be carried out; and introduction of a central registry of Important Landscape Features (ILF). (NBSAP)

Strategic Objective 1 of NBSAP 2012-2020 aims to “Improve the status of biodiversity by conserving ecosystems, species and genetic diversity and by restoring biodiversity and ecosystem services in degraded areas”.  It is mapped to 3 ABTs (ABT11, ABT 14 and ABT15) and comprises 13 priority actions. Among them, the following contribute more  specifically to ABT15:  conduct of mangrove species mapping and inventory;  rehabilitation, restoration and protection of mangrove belts; exploration of new models to combine ecological restoration and creation of small businesses in mangrove areas; assessment of the level of degradation in mined-out areas; rehabilitation and restoration of degraded areas with a particular focus on mined-out areas; promotion of soil health through the prudent utilization of biological, chemical and physical methods in an ecosystem agronomic approach. A target associated to Strategic Objective 1 is to have by, by 2015, at least 3 mined-out sites duly restored and managed. (NBSAP)

The National Plan for Nature Protection (2017-2021) highlights activities to be carried out by 2020 in relation to inter alia: establishment of green infrastructure; restoration of at least 15% of degraded ecosystems, including wetlands, richly-structured semi-open landscapes, and grasslands (including nutrient-poor grasslands and moors); decline in pollinator species; strengthening of ecosystem capacity to resist and adapt to disturbances; soil use (within the context of achieving sustainable development); promotion of the concept of green infrastructure in urban areas; restoration of ecological network connectivity.  (NBSAP)

The Eswatini Water Development Enterprise (ESWADE) conducts Land and Water Inventories to determine the state of the land and water in project areas.  The National Environment Fund under the Eswatini Environment Authority (EEA) has enabled implementation of measures aimed at community rehabilitation. The rehabilitation of dongas has been supported through the planting of trees in degraded areas and construction of gabions by stakeholders (including NGOs, government departments and parastatal organizations). The method of fencing off degraded ecosystems has been employed to protect and restore these ecosystems and the services they provide to communities. Measures have also been taken in relation to desilting and improving runoff water infiltration across the country, including: dredging of head ponds to increase dam water holding capacities reduced by siltation; construction of terrace channels to slow runoff water and promote infiltration; and construction of water diversion channels to minimize erosion. (6NR)

Priority is given to restoration of degraded ecosystems and prevention of land degradation, including protection and rational use of soil, in the national policy for sustainable development and environmental security. All ministries and agencies are required to implement the Action Plan 2014-2020 for “Priorities for Biodiversity Conservation up to 2024”. Related actions are also mainstreamed in the National Sustainable Development Strategy 2018-2023 (and 2013-2017 version), Ecological Safety Concept 2005-2020, and the National Action Plan to Combat Desertification 2015-2020.  Evidence points to negative trends in changes in carbon content in the country’s soils. The creation of artificial plantations is one of the adaptation priorities of the forest industry, for which appropriate infrastructure and funding are already in place. The Program for Nut Crops Development until 2025 is being implemented to increase forest cover. From 2014 to 2017, walnut forest crops were planted on an area of 2,771 hectares with four specialized nurseries to provide high-quality planting material. In addition, an FAO-GEF project (Sustainable Management of Mountainous Forest and Land Resources under Climate Change Conditions) was implemented from 2014 to 2019 and is expected to contribute to enhancing forest and agricultural productivity (and increase the incomes of persons living in mountainous regions), maintaining the flow of ecosystem services, including increasing carbon stocks in forest and agricultural ecosystems. (6NR)

The country’s natural environment is relatively well preserved and as such the primary focus of the nature protection sector is on conservation (restoration projects are carried out occasionally). Through the Naturavita Project 2015-2023, actions are being carried out to demine, reconstruct and protect forests, forest land and water resources in the project area, in which it is suspected still exist a significant number of minefields. Areas contaminated by mines will be rehabilitated through restoration of forests and valuable natural habitats, appropriate infrastructure for combating forest fires, educational infrastructure for raising awareness of biodiversity and mine risk, and establishment of a monitoring system which will inter alia contribute to the preservation of water of good quality.  The project aims to demine 2,534 ha of forest and forest land in the Mura-Drava Regional Park and Kopački rit Nature Park, as well as restore 1021 ha of forest (of this total, 441 ha of alien tree species will be replaced with native species). (6NR)

The National Restoration Plan was launched in 2015 and has a 20-year horizon. Local communities are participating in both implementation and monitoring which ensures that they receive direct benefits from restoration activities. A national map of areas in need of restoration has been prepared.  Work is also being carried out to establish a National Advisory Committee on Restoration. Also, through the 20x20 Initiative and the Bonn Challenge, Colombia has pledged to restore 1 000.000 ha by 2020. As of 2017, a total of 598,100 ha was in the process of being restored (actions are being taken through various planning and regulatory instruments, all of which call for rigorous social consensus and standards for integrating minorities and ethnic groups in activities). Furthermore, several restoration initiatives are being carried out within the National Natural Parks System, within the framework of the Institutional Strategic Plan (2007-2019) and the Participatory Ecological Restoration Strategy. The Colombian Network of Civil Society Nature Reserves possesses significant experience in restoration and provides support to affiliates in this area. Related research is also being carried out by various institutions, including the Humboldt Institute, the National University of Colombia, the Amazon Institute for Scientific Research, and the National Corporation of Forestry Research and Development. (6NR)

activities.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
activities.title_s: At the international level, the UK has contributed to implementation of ABT15 through support provided to countries in relation to projects initiated under The Darwin Initiative.  For example, a project, led by the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh, aims to improve livelihoods, reduce poverty, conserve biodiversity and offset carbon in Nepal through the use of invasive plant biomass for alternative, carbon-sensitive bioenergy sources. Another Darwin Initiative project, led by the University of Exeter, deals with preventing Borneo’s peatland fires to protect health, livelihood and biodiversity. This project is addressing Borneo’s biodiverse peat-swamp forests that are being destroyed by annual fires which cause huge public health problems and destroy large swathes of rainforest, while releasing carbon and contributing to climate change. The project will restore drained and deforested peatlands and encourage behaviour change amongst local communities, while simultaneously tackling fire impacts. (6NR)

title.en: Nagoya Protocol in force and operational

action.en: By 2015, the Nagoya Protocol on Access to Genetic Resources and the Fair and Equitable Sharing of Benefits Arising from their Utilization is in force and operational, consistent with national legislation.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 16 by Pierre du Plessis

activities.title_s: Ratified in October 2012, the Nagoya Protocol will be implemented through domestic legislation on ABS (Biological Diversity Act) adopted in 2002. (NBSAP)

The Government aims to support a Green Deal to apply the international ABS agreements. Through a pilot project, businesses from the Dutch breeding sector, knowledge institutions and Government will set up cooperation with similar parties from a developing country that could provide genetic resources. By the end of 2014, this should result in an agreement on access to genetic resources and the fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from the use of relevant genetic material, and could serve as a model for future ABS agreements. (NBSAP)

National Target 15 of NBSAP (2016) is mapped to ABT16. Rwanda become a Party to the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in 2014.  By 2017, the country aimed to have integrated the Protocol in national legislation and administrative practices and enforced implementation. Six actions are defined for this target;  and associated to 2020 implementation indicators that include: legal and administrative tools for the implementation of Nagoya Protocol; number of access permits; number of benefit-sharing agreements; number of awareness and training workshops; number of socio-economic infrastructures and income-generating projects initiated through revenue-sharing around protected areas; number of people compensated for damages caused by wildlife; number of socio-economic infrastructures constructed; and the volume of revenue shared per protected area. (NBSAP)

National Target 16 of NBSAP 2015-2020 is mapped to ABT16.  The Ministry of Environment and Forestry is responsible for carrying out activities to develop relevant legislation and organize implementation mechanisms at central and local levels.  Indonesia became a Party to the Protocol in 2014.  It is expected that the country’s ‘biodiversity park program’ will enhance its bargaining position in access and benefit-sharing processes.  An important function of biodiversity parks relates to biodiversity research and development, including biotechnology development. (NBSAP)

The revised NBSAP adopted in 2016 contains a national objective mapped to ABT16. Albania became a Party to the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in 2014 and was the first country in the central European region to ratify the Protocol. By 2020, it is anticipated that knowledge on the concept of access and benefit-sharing and dissemination of related information will have been increased.  By 2015, it was anticipated that the Protocol would be operational and aligned with national legislation. Possible measures to be carried out towards this end were: introduction or revision of relevant national legislation; collection and evaluation of information on forests, biological resources and their sustainable use; development of standard development models for the exchange of benefits derived from genetic resources; and definition of biological species subject to export permits. (NBSAP)

National Target D2 of NBSAP 2016-2020 is mapped to ABT16 and ABT18. NBSAP 2016-2020 is a five-year plan set within a fifteen-year framework, aligned with the Horizon 2030 national development framework and its third-phase strategy endorsed in 2015.  National Target D2 aims to, by 2025, regulate access to genetic resources and associated traditional knowledge and share benefits arising from utilization in a fair and equitable manner. Activities are planned to develop a national legislative framework for bioprospecting that defines mandates, roles and responsibilities for management of genetic resources, and determine within the 2016-2017 timeframe whether Belize will sign the Nagoya Protocol (and if so, align the national  framework accordingly). (NBSAP)

Strategic Objective 6 of the National Biodiversity Strategy adopted in 2013 is mapped to ABT16 and seeks to promote and contribute to equitable access to and sharing of benefits arising from the use of genetic resources (ABS). This strategic objective contains 5 operational objectives which respectively aim to: by 2014, have raised awareness about the concept of ABS in the context of the CBD and the Nagoya Protocol, and widely disseminated information on ABS; by 2014, have ratified and implemented the Nagoya Protocol; by 2020, have mechanisms in place to enhance national and global cooperation on ABS issues; by 2020, create operational mechanisms to protect the knowledge, innovations and practices of indigenous and local communities embodying traditional lifestyles relevant to the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity; and, by 2015, have a functional ABS Clearing-House in place. (NBSAP) (Belgium became a Party to the Nagoya Protocol in 2016.)

The country became a Party to the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in 2014.  The number of genetic materials accessed for research and development, and fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from their use, has increased. However, the diversity and quality of genetic resources for sustainable utilization should be improved. Similarly, control over illegal movement of genetic resources needs to be strengthened. The number of bio-prospected species for ABS has increased to 18 species. Nine ABS agreements have been signed on five species (Bidens macroptera, Moringa stenopetala, Aloe species, Eucalyptus species and Rhizobium bacteria (rhizobial bio-fertilizer). Seven routes of illegal movements of genetic resources in the country have been identified and 10 ABS experts assigned to regulate the unauthorized movement of genetic resources at entry and exit windows. (6NR)

The country became a Party to the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in 2016. In 2018, the country adopted the Act on Conditions of Utilization of Genetic Resources under the Nagoya Protocol, further to EU Regulation No. 511 (April 2014) of the European Parliament and Council on compliance measures for users from the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in the European Union (aligning EU rules with international obligations). The European Union ratified the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in May 2014. (6NR)

The country became a Party to the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in 2015. The country has developed national policy (2018) and a national regulation (2017) on ABS. Work is currently underway to establish a regulatory framework for genetic resources.  The country also intends to develop an inventory on traditional knowledge. Research on genetic diversity is being strengthened through the National Fund for Innovation and Scientific and Technological Development of the Ministry of Higher Education, Science and Technology, and encompasses projects on bioprospecting. A practical guide for the application of the regulation on access to genetic resources, associated Traditional Knowledge and fair and equitable distribution of benefits was prepared in 2018.  Capacity-building activities aimed at local communities are being implemented. The country is also promoting the ratification of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) to which it is currently a signatory. (6NR)

The country became a Party to the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in 2016. Germany has adopted national legislation for implementing the Protocol and is also actively participating in the development of implementing legislation at the EU level.  Germany has also provided support to other countries in regard to establishing and/or increasing the effectiveness of national ABS structures. Germany has been a Party to the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture (ITPGRFA) since 2004 and has made more than 115,000 accessions of plant genetic resources available in the ITPGRFA multilateral system. (6NR)

The country became a Party to the Nagoya Protocol on ABS in 2017 and adopted the National Act on Access and Benefit Sharing of Genetic Resources the same year. There are plans to revise this Act at an unspecified time. Competent National Authorities (persons authorized to grant users access to genetic resources and represent providers on a local or national level) and checkpoints (persons authorized to collect or receive information provided by users on the use of genetic resources) have been designated. An Integrated Reporting Service for Genetic Resources has been launched. The registration of genetic resources for national management and the designation of biological resources subject to out-of-the-country transportation permit has expanded. The Ministry of Science and ICT (MSIT) has published and distributed guidelines for researchers, including the ABS Guide and ABS Brief. (6NR)

action.en: By 2015 each Party has developed, adopted as a policy instrument, and has commenced implementing an effective, participatory and updated national biodiversity strategy and action plan.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 17 by Roberto Cavalcanti
20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 17 by Caroline Petersen

activities.title_s: The National Biodiversity Conservation Strategy 2010-2030 functions as a policy umbrella over other more specific national frameworks, and a guiding policy framework for the diverse Australian, state, territory and local government and private sector approaches to conservation. (NBSAP)

The National Biodiversity Strategy 2011-2020 is prioritized in all public policy and at every territorial scale (e.g. water, soil, sea, climate, energy, agriculture, forestry, spatial planning, infrastructure, industry, trade, education, research, health). (NBSAP)
The NBSAP 2011-2020 is a guiding policy framework for district and sub-district authorities, and for civil society groups and the private sector. (NBSAP)

programs.title: NBSAP webpage

action.en: By 2020, the traditional knowledge, innovations and practices of indigenous and local communities relevant for the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity, and their customary use of biological resources, are respected, subject to national legislation and relevant international obligations, and fully integrated and reflected in the implementation of the Convention with the full and effective participation of indigenous and local communities, at all relevant levels.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 18 by Malia Nobrega
20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 18 by Joji Carino

activities.title_s: The Forestry Research Institute is implementing a project on “Useful Plants of Malawi” where Traditional Knowledge is used to identify plants that are useful for nutrition, cosmetics and pharmaceutical use. (NBSAP)

A new Strategic Plan of Action to 2020 exists for Sabah state.  The first Plan contributed to implementing the Heart of Borneo Initiative by empowering communities in the management of local natural resources, through the promotion of Indigenous Community and Conserved Areas using the Tagal traditional river management system. (NBSAP)
National legislation is in place that recognises tangata whenua (indigenous communities) and their Mātauranga Māori (Traditional Knowledge that underpins Māori culture and identity). (NBSAP)

Objectives 7, 8 and 9 of NBSAP 2016-2030 are mapped to ABT18 and will contribute to the development of a biodiversity knowledge management system, integrating various databases, for disseminating knowledge on biodiversity and its importance for inclusive sustainable development, among decision-makers, sectors, teachers, researchers and beneficiaries, and for raising awareness of issues among the public at large. This system will promote inter alia the values of traditional knowledge, best practices and opportunities for green growth. (NBSAP)

Preliminary Target 9 of NBSAP 2014-2017 is mapped to ABT18. In the medium term (within 1 to 5 years), the country anticipated having developed a profile of traditional knowledge, innovations and practices regarding use of biodiversity resources in Afghanistan. In the long term (within 5 to 10 years), the country anticipates having identified and implemented mechanisms for ensuring the rights of indigenous and local communities over their traditional knowledge, practices and benefit-sharing. (NBSAP)

National Targets C.4 and E.3 of NBSAP 2014-2020 are mapped to ABT18. Objectives of Target C.4 aim to increase the effectiveness of protected areas management through increasing the level of stakeholder involvement, especially local communities, with due regard to gender equality, in the planning and management of protected areas, and to create support mechanisms for biodiversity protection and sustainable use with the participation of local communities and the private sector.  Entities responsible for implementation are the Agency of Protected Areas, local governments and other stakeholders.  The objective of Target E.3 is to restore traditional knowledge related to biodiversity (including agrarian biodiversity) conservation and sustainable use through establishing effective mechanisms for public communication and participation in decisions made at all levels on the use of natural resources and integrate the interest and traditional knowledge in biodiversity conservation of local peoples in legislation and strategies. Entities responsible for implementation are the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources Protection, research organizations and NGOs. (NBSAP)

Through Target 1 of NBSAP 2012-2022, the country aims to, by 2022, have communicated and protected collective scientific knowledge and traditional knowledge associated with biological diversity, including knowledge linked to genetic resources, through implementation of integrated research processes, classification processes and legal or sui generis frameworks. (NBSAP)

National Target E-2 of the National Biodiversity Strategy 2012-2020 is mapped to ABT18 (and ABT 19 and ABT20). Activities are being carried out to re-evaluate traditional knowledge “wisdom”, including techniques for resource use that have been cultivated in response to the natural characteristics of local regions over a long period of time, with a view to passing this traditional knowledge down to the next generations, promoting its use and mainstreaming it in plans. The Ministry of Environment and the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology are responsible implementing entities. (NBSAP)

Efforts are being carried out to identify the traditional knowledge, innovations and practices of local communities relevant to the conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity. Local community participation is integrated in biodiversity conservation strategies and sustainable development strategies.  Numerous capacity-building programmes are being carried out to support the sustainable use of resources by local communities (for example, a particular method is being used to collect and regenerate medicinal and aromatic plants), and in relation to creation of new sources of income (value chains) for local communities based on biodiversity activities.  Through the GEF-supported Global Support Initiative for Indigenous Peoples and Community-Conserved Territories and Areas (ICCA-GSI), actions are also being taken to expand conservation areas managed by local communities. The main objective of this Initiative is to enhance recognition, support and overall effectiveness of ICCAs for biodiversity conservation through sustainable livelihoods and self-strengthening action. Also, various projects aim to integrate sustainable conservation practices used by local communities into a national strategic framework (such a framework does not exist at present). (6NR)

A Traditional Knowledge Digital Library (TKDL) has been established by the Ministry of Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha and Homoeopathy (AYUSH), in collaboration with the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR).  TKDL contains transcriptions of more than 2.90 lakh medical formulations of Ayurveda Unani and Siddha in five recognized international languages. Grassroots organizations, such as the Foundation for Revitalization of Local Health Traditions (FRLHT), a Centre of Excellence under the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, work with the local communities to document, add value and protect grassroots innovations. (6NR)

The Bolivian Government is committed to conserving biodiversity and developing sustainable production systems through the implementation of non-market-based approaches and integrated community-based management by Indigenous Peoples, campesino communities and small-scale producers. In 2010, Bolivia adopted the historic Law on the Rights of Mother Earth. This was followed by the adoption of the Framework Law on Mother Earth and Integral Development for Living Well (“Vivir Bien”) in 2012, focused primarily on climate change mitigation and adaptation although clearly stressing the importance of implementing holistic measures for biodiversity and cultural conservation to “live well”. (6NR)

The incorporation of Indigenous Knowledge (IK) is already a valuable contributor to the effectiveness of Canada’s various biodiversity initiatives, providing information regarding the sustainable use of plants and animals, as well as the relationships and current stresses in ecosystems. Environment and Climate Change Canada (ECCC) has initiated steps to maintain information on federal and provincial/territorial mechanisms in place across the country that allow for Indigenous Knowledge (IK) to inform government decision-making. However, this work is in its early stages and data available for this assessment is inconclusive. Information on Indigenous languages (important repositories of IK) is collected regularly by Statistics Canada; however, the most comprehensive data to demonstrate trends in linguistic diversity is not yet available.  (6NR)

action.en: By 2020, knowledge, the science base and technologies relating to biodiversity, its values, functioning, status and trends, and the consequences of its loss, are improved, widely shared and transferred, and applied.

videos.caption: 20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 19 by Jennifer Rubis
20/20 Talks: Aichi Biodiversity Target 19 by Randall Garcia

activities.title_s: The Belgium Ecosystem Services (BEES) network, a community of practice aiming to connect different societal actors involved in ecosystem services research, practice and policy-making was launched in April 2012. (NBSAP)
A national system for deforestation and carbon monitoring has been developed. (NBSAP)

In 2012, the German Research Association (DFG) decided to support a research centre for integrative biodiversity research (€33 million over a five-year period, including eight new professorships). (NBSAP)
The National University of Mongolia has developed a curriculum on the assessment and monitoring of biodiversity for Ph.D. students. (NBSAP)
A Centre of Excellence on Biodiversity has been established (University of Rwanda/Ministry of Education). (NBSAP)

Action Plan 19 of NBSAP (2016) is mapped to ABT19.  The Action Plan contains two strategic objectives: to use science and technology for disseminating biostatistics for the effective management of biodiversity; and to enhance research and development in agricultural biodiversity. By the end of 2017, the country aimed to have initiated biodiversity publications, websites, social media presence and have disseminated biodiversity information nationally and internationally. By mid-2018, it aimed to have identified and published research gaps for improving agricultural biodiversity conservation and, by the end of 2018, have trained or engaged personnel in programs in biodiversity and agriculture. (NBSAP)

Target 19 of NBSAP (2016) is mapped to ABT19.  By 2020, the country aims to establish and maintain in responsible institutions, for wide sharing among stakeholders, an interoperable and user-friendly information system containing data and information on biodiversity (including its associated ecosystem services) values, functions, status and trends, and threats, and the consequences of its loss.  This target is associated to two specific actions on improving the existing Clearing-House Mechanism and its accessibility to serve at the science-policy interface and facilitate more informed decision-making, and strengthening institutions and research providing relevant data and information. (NBSAP)

Target 12 of NBSAP 2016-2020 is mapped to ABT19 and aims to improve the scientific knowledge about the modern state of biological diversity, define trends and causes of the state dynamics of species and biotopes, elaborate effective measures for sustainable use and monitoring of biological diversity, and create a platform for the exchange of information and knowledge. Planned results include: maintenance of the State cadastres (registers) on flora and fauna; improvement of the forest inventory system; maintenance of the respective State cadastres (registers) on forests, land, water and greenhouse gas emissions; effective monitoring of flora and fauna and the ecological systems within protected areas; ensuring the annual ringing of migratory birds; and the establishment and operationalization of the national Clearing-House Mechanism. (NBSAP)

National Target 19 of NBSAP 2014-2025 is mapped to ABT19.  This target aims to implement a knowledge management system for national biodiversity by 2020.  Planned activities to achieve this target include inter alia: establishment of a forum where researchers, conservation managers and decision-makers can share information and determine the type of information that is most useful for improving the conservation of biodiversity; and establishment of the relevant national clearing-house mechanisms on biodiversity, biosafety and access and benefit-sharing (ABS) issues required through the Convention on Biological Diversity. (NBSAP)

National Target 4 of NBSAP 2016-2020 is mapped to ABT19. This target aims to increase by 2020 the level of natural ecosystems that are benefiting from pest management. For example, actions are being carried out to protect kauri which are among the largest species of tree in the world and are only found in New Zealand, but are threatened by a disease thought to be introduced to New Zealand sometime in the middle of the 20th century. The disease is spread through infected soil and plant material and no natural resistance has been observed. The Kauri Dieback Programme is a partnership between government agencies, Māori and philanthropists and seeks to protect kauri by preventing people spreading the disease and investment in science to create new tools for disease management. (NBSAP)

Various actions have been implemented or are ongoing related to ABT19.  For example, the integration of Science, Technology and Innovation in national productive processes was considered central to the success of the government’s policy priorities and programmes outlined in Kenya Vision 2030. The Natural Product Initiative was prioritized as one of the flagship projects of the Vision 2030 which aims to create an interface between indigenous knowledge and Science, Technology, Innovation and business expertise, spur home-grown innovation culture and promote quality production and growth while developing Kenyan unique products that meet national and international standards. Proposed policies include the Natural Products Policy, National Intellectual Property Policy, National Innovation Policy, and the Indigenous knowledge and Technology Policy. In addition, the following bills are under review: Biosciences Bill, Kenya Institute of Nanotechnology Legal Framework, and the Natural Products Bill. (6NR)
The country has developed the BioNNA (Biodiversity National Network of Albania) web portal (http://www.bionna.al/), providing access to a data-sharing system to support NBSAP implementation. (6NR)

In 2014, the country revised its Organic Law on Science, Technology and Innovation (Ley Orgánica de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación) whose purpose is to develop guiding principles in the area of science, technology and innovation and related applications. It also foresees the creation of the National Fund for Science, Technology and Innovation. The law promotes collaboration   between government authorities and the people. (6NR)

Various research projects are contributing to ABT19.  For example, a project is underway to establish the basis for creating a uniform federal ecosystem monitoring method that can be used to obtain previously unavailable data about the status and development of ecosystems. Other work is being carried out to investigate the role played by road, railway and waterway verges in the conservation of biodiversity and ecological connectivity and what measures to promote biodiversity are possible when creating and maintaining transport infrastructure. Another example is the ‘Bridging in Biodiversity Science’ (BIBS) project which is investigating the various ecosystem processes and their interactions (aquatic-terrestrial, above ground-below ground) at various scales based on different environmental disciplines, as well as the processes by which biodiversity adapts to urban spaces. The integrative approach in BIBS is innovative and is leading to new knowledge in the area of biodiversity research. (6NR)

The CBD-CHM Korea (www.cbd-chm.go.kr) has been established to manage and disseminate information on biodiversity and biological resources held by related organizations and the private sector in Korea. Relatedly, the Ministry of Science and ICT, in charge of the Korean Bioinformation Center, operates the Bio-Resource Information System (KOBIS). The Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs, the Korean Forest Service, and the Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries are also respectively contributing data and information to this information system. Korea also continues to provide support for various ongoing projects, such the Bio-Bridge Initiative, Peace and Biodiversity Dialogue Initiative, Korean Biosafety Capacity Building Initiative, Forest Ecosystem Restoration Initiative, and the Sustainable Ocean Initiative, which is contributing to building capacity at the international level for implementing the Convention. (6NR)

title.en: Financial resources from all sources increased

action.en: By 2020, at the latest, the mobilization of financial resources for effectively implementing the Strategic Plan for Biodiversity 2011-2020 from all sources, and in accordance with the consolidated and agreed process in the Strategy for Resource Mobilization, should increase substantially from the current levels. This target will be subject to changes contingent to resource needs assessments to be developed and reported by Parties.

activities.title_s: Resource mobilization figures for nature preservation indicate an annual contribution of DKK 2.3 billion, equivalent to USD 390 million/year (average for 2006-2010), corresponding to approximately DKK 410 per person/year, or 0.13% of the GNP. (NBSAP)

The country is participating in the Biodiversity Finance Initiative (BIOFIN) launched by UNDP in 2012, to determine the costs of NBSAP implementation define financial gaps and design a strategy for mobilizing financial resources. (NBSAP)

An innovative objective of the draft programme of the National Fund for Environmental Protection and Water Management 2014-2020 is to pilot a financial support mechanism for biodiversity-friendly enterprises. (NBSAP)
